PRO

Far as I know Iranians are after peaceful aims unlike president Bush just crazy about wars. American developments of new generation of nukes are no secret. They call them Bunker Busters, which are designed to attack deeply buried hardened targets. Each new weapon needs testing. That's the logic of all the military. So the mention by White House reps of some underground facilities in Parchin, Iran, is not just by chance. Americans assert that those facilities are used for nuclear research and developments. Is it where America's going to conduct tests of the 'prodigy weapon'? 
 FYI Parchin is only 30 km south-west of Teheran. And there are chemical factories there as well. In case of bombing with Bunker Busters, whether large or small, the chemical agents could be spread in the surrounding areas.

post_info.post_title: Why do Americans make so much noise about the Iran nuclear program?

wilted_laughter
Well if Iran says it's nuclear programme is peaceful then it MUST be true. emoticon_rolleyes
gamehuis

Well the thing is, the Iranians aren't even given the benefit of doubt.
 As one of the larger producers of oil, Iran would know how much oil is left. If they think that oil is going to run out soon, it would be logical to assume that in order to avoid a major energy crisis they would need to have alternative ways to create energy.
 I for one applaud the Iranian nuclear program and I wish that us Europeans would take such a pro-active stance with regards to energy. But alas, the hippy treehuggers always block any attempt to build more nuclear powerplants. Let's see how they react when they only have 2 hours of electricity per day.
 
 As for the US bitching, well that's to be expected. Afterall, they see terrorists everywhere now.
wilted_laughter

Well the thing is, the Iranians aren't even given the benefit of doubt.
 As one of the larger producers of oil, Iran would know how much oil is left. If they think that oil is going to run out soon, it would be logical to assume that in order to avoid a major energy crisis they would need to have alternative ways to create energy. 

 
 Interesting.

Just because Bush raises cain about Iran and their nuclear developments doesn't mean Americans are doing the same. Many American do not support Bush, even though he somehow keeps getting votes. emoticon_rolleyes 
 
 In fact, I haven't even read much about it in a couple of months.
Clive14

Just because Bush raises cain about Iran and their nuclear developments doesn't mean Americans are doing the same. Many American do not support Bush, even though he somehow keeps getting votes. emoticon_rolleyes 
 
 In fact, I haven't even read much about it in a couple of months.
This is probably because Bush is currently hanging on to the Lebanon band wagon trying to claim it is another example of America "encouraging democracy in the Middle East" and still stuck in Iraq with no exit policy. He's been forced to allow the European "appeasers" the chance to talk Iran into adopting a nuclear programme that is open to inspection as he can't spare the resources to act in his usual beligerent fashion toward Iran too.
gamehuis

Agree, no harm in having inspectors in Iran though.

 Naturally. It would certainly ease everybody's minds. 
 But one also has to look at it from an Iranian point of view. The US has always supported the Shah of Iran, who was basically a dictator who oppressed the people. This in turn has made the US (and by extension 'the West') extremely hated and distrusted by the Iranians. If I were the Iranian government I wouldn't let the West inspect my nuclear powerplants either. Would the US allow North Korea to have a look at US nuclear powerplants?
wilted_laughter

Naturally. It would certainly ease everybody's minds. 
 But one also has to look at it from an Iranian point of view. The US has always supported the Shah of Iran, who was basically a dictator who oppressed the people. This in turn has made the US (and by extension 'the West') extremely hated and distrusted by the Iranians. If I were the Iranian government I wouldn't let the West inspect my nuclear powerplants either. Would the US allow North Korea to have a look at US nuclear powerplants?

 
 True......
Jeffersonian

Far as I know Iranians are after peaceful aims unlike president Bush just crazy about wars. American developments of new generation of nukes are no secret. They call them Bunker Busters, which are designed to attack deeply buried hardened targets. Each new weapon needs testing. That's the logic of all the military. So the mention by White House reps of some underground facilities in Parchin, Iran, is not just by chance. Americans assert that those facilities are used for nuclear research and developments. Is it where America's going to conduct tests of the 'prodigy weapon'? 
 FYI Parchin is only 30 km south-west of Teheran. And there are chemical factories there as well. In case of bombing with Bunker Busters, whether large or small, the chemical agents could be spread in the surrounding areas.

 
 Stop.
 
 Think for a minute.
 --------------------------
 As far as I know.........
 --------------------------
 
 Everything you wrote after that is really a guess isn't? You really don't know what the Iranian will do with nukes.
 
 Well I will point out to you, that the Iranians and the USA are sworn enemies. Does that sound peaceful to you? Plus the Iranians are 'understanding' of the mission by Al Queda. Do you think or not think that a government with nukes friendly to Al Queda should be somthing the USA should REALLY REALLY be worried about? I think we should.
pickleweaseler
How is this related to gun control?
Duo_Maxwell

Actually, I think Iran is doing it to produce nuclear weapons. 
 
 Why? Because Bush sent a message post 9/11 that if you have a nuke, America won't bother you. 
 
 Think about it, if the world's superpower has a pattern of letting those with nukes do what they want, why wouldn't you want to get one as soon as you can?
 
 Speaking of which, what DOES this have to do with gun control? 
 
 Yes, I understand ARMS control, but that's quite a leap.
zelma

Actually, I think Iran is doing it to produce nuclear weapons. 
 
 Why? Because Bush sent a message post 9/11 that if you have a nuke, America won't bother you. 
 
 Think about it, if the world's superpower has a pattern of letting those with nukes do what they want, why wouldn't you want to get one as soon as you can?
 
 Whatt??? All this time, I thought Bush wanted to dethrone Saddam Hussein and stop his weapons of mass destruction--didn't that include nukes??
 
 And when did Bush every say that if someone has a nuke, America won't bother you?
 
 Your whole post is unfounded.
daewoo

Whatt??? All this time, I thought Bush wanted to dethrone Saddam Hussein and stop his weapons of mass destruction--didn't that include nukes??
 
 And when did Bush every say that if someone has a nuke, America won't bother you?
 
 Your whole post is unfounded.

 
 Unfounded? Post 9/11 we invaded Iraq, a third tier nation with no weapons of mass destruction, and even if they DID have them, we knew for a fact they had no delivery system capable of reaching us. 
 
 North Korea, on the other hand, with nukes targeting US cities, and sitting on top of missiles capable of getting them here, is getting a good talking to, and we are probably going to give them billions of dollars in hopes that they will discontinue their program.
 
 If I was the leader of ANY nation right now, I would be working my butt off to secure nukes. Jusdging from the actions of the US in recent years, they are the only defense you have,
Duo_Maxwell

Whatt??? All this time, I thought Bush wanted to dethrone Saddam Hussein and stop his weapons of mass destruction--didn't that include nukes??
 
 And when did Bush every say that if someone has a nuke, America won't bother you?
 
 Your whole post is unfounded.

 
 Daewoo refuted you. But I have still something to say. During the end of the first gulf war, one comment from a Indian Journalist went worldwide, "If you go to war with America, bring nukes." 
 
 Why is it that for some reason, after Bush's axis of evil, North Korea restarted their nuclear development? 
 
 Consider this: when was the last time America bothered someone militarily who had nukes? 
 
 *thinking*
 
 *thinking*
 
 *thinking*
 
 never
CvT

Anyone who says that North Korea has been spared military action solely because of nukes is either stunningly ignorant or simply being disingenuous.
 
 North Korea doesn't need nukes to deter an attack. It has more than 1,000 heavy artillery pieces ranged in on most of South Korea's population.
 
 Any US military action would reduce Seoul and its environs into a shell-torn wasteland.
 
 North Korea doesn't need nukes to defend itself. For 50 years its been digging in heavy artillery. The US cannot silence those guns fast enough. They are too well protected and there are too many of them. In a matter of hours, Most of South Korea's capital would lie in smoking ruins.
 
 No nukes needed.
 
 So before you start announcing what other countries think, you may want to examine the strategic balance of forces and the local geography.
 
 Unless a would-be dictator can arrange to have millions of other people live within shellfire of the largest concentration of heavy artillery on the planet, the deterrence value is severely compromised.
 
 Now someone tell me what this has to do with gun control? emoticon_confused
Duo_Maxwell

actually the vast majority of NK's artillery (which they have more then a 1,000) is shell based and lacks range over 10 miles. Seoul is 38 miles from the DMZ. Seoul's only real fear is from short range nuclear strikes or missile strikes. Should NK open up, any missile launch would instantly be tracked, targeted and destroyed within minutes. Not to mention that South korea employs antimissile defenses to deal with such threats. It's the DMZ that is going to get pounded to dust. Hence why we have moved US troops away.
 
 So in reality, while that is a deterrent, it's not a very big one to American attacks. A nuclear missile aimed at LA is.
gamehuis
So what are the chances that NK is just pretending to have nukes (kinda like Saddam with his WMDs), so that the US will leave them alone?
Duo_Maxwell

So what are the chances that NK is just pretending to have nukes (kinda like Saddam with his WMDs), so that the US will leave them alone?

 
 It's possible. But if you're going to pretend, you minus well just make the blasted thing, you're already producing alot of the stuff you need anyways. To fake that you have nukes you need to run a number of chemical processes, mainly producing specific byproduct gases that only come from enriching weapons grade uranium or plutonium. So once you have the WGU/P it's not a big step towards the actual weapon. And we know NK has delivery systems (unlike Iraq), so that's another incentive to just make it.
gamehuis
I know that they have the facilities to make them, but what if they're a still few years away from actually having a working weapon and are saying that they already have them to buy some time?
CvT

If you think Seoul's "only real fear" is from WMD, I suggest you do further reading.
 
 Conventional deterrence is not obsolete and North Korea retains it in spades.
 
 The US and ROK militaries do not have the ability to strike at North Korea with impunity, and that is why they have chosen the negotiated route.
 
 If anything, North Korea's nuclear ambitions have undermined its position as it makes military action more, not less palatable.
 
 The conventional threat posed by North Korea is considerable, but it pales by comparison to what nuclear weapons can do. Thus, using a crude cost-benefit analysis, better to take some shells now rather than risk radioactive long-distance strikes later.
 
 They key to dealing with North Korea is China. China has the power to curb North Korea's ambitions short of war and everyone knows it. China must be shown that the advantages of North Korean nuclear weapons are offset by the disadvantages.
 
 That is why the US is working through a six-power system rather than forcing the issue.
 
 A remilitarized Japan threatens the entire Asian rim - particularly China. If China allows North Korea to go nuclear, the US could counter by encouraging and enabling similar technologies in Taiwan and Japan.
 
 That is the reason why we have taken a different approach. In Iraq, all of the options short of war were exhausted. That is not the case in East Asia.
Duo_Maxwell

If you think Seoul's "only real fear" is from WMD, I suggest you do further reading.
 
 Conventional deterrence is not obsolete and North Korea retains it in spades.

 
 But in terms of actually artillery, Seoul is relatively safe. It's the DMZ that is going to be litterally oblierated. 
 
 

 The US and ROK militaries do not have the ability to strike at North Korea with impunity, and that is why they have chosen the negotiated route.

 
 I never said they did. Merely that we could strike back. 
 
 

 If anything, North Korea's nuclear ambitions have undermined its position as it makes military action more, not less palatable.

 
 How so? When was the last time America bothered someone militarily who had a nuke? Oh wait, never. 
 
 

 The conventional threat posed by North Korea is considerable, but it pales by comparison to what nuclear weapons can do. Thus, using a crude cost-benefit analysis, better to take some shells now rather than risk radioactive long-distance strikes later.

 
 True, but that goes out the window if they already have it. We will risk combat coventially, We will not risk combat with nuclear weapons on the table. Thus is the difference. The threat of Us attack does go up during production, that I won't argue, but the threat of US attack drops suddenly once you got a nuke or two, or perferably ten. 
 
 

 They key to dealing with North Korea is China. China has the power to curb North Korea's ambitions short of war and everyone knows it. China must be shown that the advantages of North Korean nuclear weapons are offset by the disadvantages.

 
 Actually all china needs to do is to cut off aid, except Bejing isn't stupid, and will not let a buffer zone disappear. 
 
 

 That is why the US is working through a six-power system rather than forcing the issue.

 
 Actually it's more likely the US realizes that NK has nukes and there's not much we can do to stop them. 
 
 

 A remilitarized Japan threatens the entire Asian rim - particularly China. 

 
 Japan has been remilitarized for quite some time. Their airforce is superb, as well as their ground forces. Their navy has been in several skirmishs as well. Not to mention all of their stuff is top notch in equipment sense. 
 
 
If China allows North Korea to go nuclear, the US could counter by encouraging and enabling similar technologies in Taiwan and Japan.

 
 Tokyo can go nuclear in 3 months or less. It has enough nuclear material to produce thousands of warheads, has the ability to turn space transportation rockets into ICBMs, and has the technological know how to fill in the rest, along with deep pockets. 
 
 

 That is the reason why we have taken a different approach. In Iraq, all of the options short of war were exhausted. That is not the case in East Asia.

 
 I'll let Daewoo handle that out.
daewoo

Conventional deterrence is not obsolete and North Korea retains it in spades.

 
 We could effectively destroy N koreas border defenses in a matter of a coupleof weeks of intensive bombing, and their offensive abilty (abilty to act outside their own borders) is nill in a conventional capacity. Their great equlaiser is the ability to put a mushroom cloud over Los Angeles, and the knowledge that hina would back their play if they used nuslear deterrent against invasion.
 
 
If anything, North Korea's nuclear ambitions have undermined its position as it makes military action more, not less palatable.

 
 How do you figure? While their attempts to gain weapons may have increased the chance of military intervention, now that they have them, military intervention is off the table. It was questionable whether or not we could "take" N Korea in a conventional war, since they would undoubtedly have chinese backing (If you will remember, we were beaten, and beaten rather badly last time around). Add their nuclear ability to that, including the fact that while the world would likely tun a blind eye to the use of nuclear weapons as a purtely defensive measure, but almost certainly NOT tot he use of like force by the US, the agressor in this case, it essentially makes a war on the korean penninsula unwinnable. 
 
 
They key to dealing with North Korea is China. China has the power to curb North Korea's ambitions short of war and everyone knows it. China must be shown that the advantages of North Korean nuclear weapons are offset by the disadvantages.

 
 This is absolutly correct. Unfortunatly, the Chinese do not seem to have any problem with N Korea having nukes, nor do they seem inclined to support our efforts to disarm them. While the US has adopted a policy of "stabilization", that is, keeping those on top on top and keeping other nations down, china, and much of the rest of the world, seems tired of beiong "stabilized". There is virtually no chance that the chinese will intervene on our behalf as far as the korean situation goes. All it would take is a word from Beijing, and the Korean weapions program would be gone tomorrow. It seems far more likely that the Chinese and Koreans both will milk this for all it is worth. The koreans will hold out for billions of dollars in aid and trade agreements (the EU is all kinds of ready with the trade relations), and China will play the N korean card as a way to gett he arms embargo against them lifted, in whihc case they will assure N Koreas defense using their own nuclear aresenal, as well as having all kinds of bright, shiny new weapons to pass across the border to them. 
 
 This may all be a moot point in the end, though, since it appears that the EU will likely lift the arms embargo against china, or at least their part of it, in return for market share in chinas domestic markets and their up and coming arms business. If they (the chinese) can pull this off without having to move on the Krean situtation, it is unlikely we will ever see any "improvement" in that area.
 
 The days of the US standing on high and passing down proclomations as far as who may and may not defend themselves with nuclear weapons are apparently over. It has become crystal clear that, while we may posture and rattle the sabre, we are unwilling to step up to a real threat. While invading a third tier nation, already crippled after years of sanctions, relying on a army composed of 20 yr old russian gear and conscript soldiers, seems to still be within our power, stepping up to a nation where our casualties may well consist of an entire US battlegroup in the first 3 hours of the war is apparently not. 
 
 While our leaders are apparently willing to "bang of war in order to whip the citizenry into a patriotic fervor" at the cost of only a few americans lives, they are not willing to risk the widescale casualties associated with taking on a nuclear armed nation. 
 
 
A remilitarized Japan threatens the entire Asian rim - particularly China. If China allows North Korea to go nuclear, the US could counter by encouraging and enabling similar technologies in Taiwan and Japan.

 
 Yea, right. The fact that Taiwan has not already been nuked off the map is based almost entirely on hopes by China that they will be able to bring them back into the fold so to speak with their industrial and trade infrastructure intact. The minute it starts to look like Taiwan might actually be a threat, especially a nuclear threat, china will obliterate Taiwan. AThey do not even have to use nukes to do it. Taiwan does not have the massive patriot missile defense network that S Korea has, and even if they did, the chinese ar more than capable of sending enoguh firepower their way in order to take down taiwan. They would not even have to go nuclear,. They could easily wipe them out with conventional missiles, and without a single chinese casualty. Japan is in the same boat. they simply are not big enough, nor do they have enough people, to start annoying China. Besides, why would they? The Japanese have thrown their lot in with the chinese in most respects. They have hundreds of billions, maybe even trillions, invested in the chinese economy and helping to get it off the ground. I would hazartd to guess that, should things actually come to a head between the US and China, the japanese would be right in line behind the Europeans to back China. there is simply too much invested there. Nobody is going to back a has been consumer economy like the US against an up and coming industrialist nation like china.
 
 
That is the reason why we have taken a different approach. In Iraq, all of the options short of war were exhausted. That is not the case in East Asia.

 
 Yes, all the options had been exhausted. We had UN inspectors inspecting gardening sheds and outhouses, and still no WMDs, Saddam was still taking only Euros for oil, and the Sauds were still kicking us out of our bases there. We werte at the end of the line. We either had to drop all the BS and end the sanctions, which would effectively have been the end of the petro dollar, the end of US direct involvement in the ME, and the start of some very difficult question from the international community with the release of the UN inspectors final report, like, "Why did we starve a million children to death when the UN inspectors declared Iraq WMD free 10 years ago?"
 
 You can twist it however you want, but at the end of the day, nations all over the world are clamoring for nuclear weapons in order to defend themselves against the American threat, and it seems that they are meeting with some sucess. I will remind you again that the very week G Bush said "We will not allow Syria to pursue nuclear technology", the russians shipped the first of many loads of reactor parts to Syria.
georged

They key to dealing with North Korea is China. China has the power to curb North Korea's ambitions short of war and everyone knows it. China must be shown that the advantages of North Korean nuclear weapons are offset by the disadvantages.
 
 That is the reason why we have taken a different approach. In Iraq, all of the options short of war were exhausted. That is not the case in East Asia.

 
 N. Korea is China's military Israel. Keeps other nations on their toes. 
 
 What options were exhausted? Iraq had complied with all UN sanctions. We found no WMDs. That Saddam was taking Euros instead of USD for oil and the Pentagon wanting ME bases were the only issues. Unless, of course, you're a believer in the propaganda that Iraq was a danger to the US, a real joke.
zelma

Daewoo refuted you. But I have still something to say. During the end of the first gulf war, one comment from a Indian Journalist went worldwide, "If you go to war with America, bring nukes."  
 
 Did we nuke Iraq? or Afghanistan?
Duo_Maxwell

Did we nuke Iraq? or Afghanistan?

 
 How is that relevant? Our use is quite irrevelant. Their polential use is key. 
 
 You obviously ignored the question, merely because if you answered, you'd admit you are wrong. 
 
 When was the last time America bothered someone militarily who had nukes? 
 
 NEVER
 
 Get a nuke, and America won't bother you.
SymonTemplar

North Korea could cause massive damage to Seoul very quicly if it chose to.
 
 "According to some reports, the DPRK has about 200 of these launchers in service. North Korea continues to improve its military. Highlighting these enhancements is an ambitious program to improve ground forces capabilities. A key component of this initiative involves the deployment of large numbers of long-range 240mm multiple rocket launcher systems and 170mm self-propelled guns to hardened sites located near the Demilitarized Zone.
 
 According to one report, a South Korean security analyst suggested that DPRK artillery pieces of calibers 170mm and 240mm "could fire 10,000 rounds per minute to Seoul and its environs." North Korea has about 500 long-range artillery tubes within range of Seoul, and the total rate of fire of thjese artillery pieces would be between 2,000 and 4,000 rounds per minute. The DPRK's two hundred 240mm MRLs fire either 12 or 22 rounds, providing a maximum single salvo of no more than 4,400 rounds.
 
 These launchers can fire a first strike of many thousands of missiles and return in a few minutes to protected caves or to alternate firing positions. The MRLs move out from underground facilities (UGFs), fire from preplanned firing positions, and return to the UGFs. Examination of the available data on the UGF sites suggests that a number of possible "exit and return" methods for the MRLs may be possible. In this case, the launchers move directly from the firing points to the UGFs. This procedure makes it difficult to target the launchers, because once they fire it only takes 75 seconds to return to their UGFs. The MRLs can fire their complete set of rockets in 44 seconds. Data from the Joint Precision Strike Demonstration Project Office indicates that the crew then needs two minutes to lower the launcher, raise the stabilizing pads, and quickly return to the UGF. This gives a total exposure time of 164 seconds. However, it is possible that the MRLs could displace faster than the JSPD case or that they might take longer. "
 
 http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/dprk/m-1985-mrl.htm
 
 http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/dprk/army.htm
